title: Kimchi Jjigae (Kimchi Stew)
description: A hearty, savory Korean stew built on well-fermented kimchi, soft tofu, and pork, simmered in a flavorful broth until rich and tangy. Bright, spicy, and deeply comforting with umami from gochujang and anchovy-stock base.

ingredients.display_name: well-fermented napa cabbage kimchi, roughly chopped
ingredients.notes: squeeze lightly to remove excess brine if extremely wet

ingredients.display_name: pork belly or pork shoulder, thinly sliced
soft (silken/medium) tofu, cut into 2 cm cubes

ingredients.notes: about 4 cups; can use homemade anchovy-kelp broth for more umami

ingredients.display_name: scallions (green onions), trimmed and cut into 3 cm pieces
ingredients.notes: separate white and green parts if desired
balances acidity if kimchi is very sour

ingredients.display_name: dried anchovies (optional for stock) or 1 tbsp anchovy sauce
ingredients.notes: if making anchovy stock; remove before serving

steps.text: Prepare ingredients: chop kimchi, slice pork, cut tofu into cubes, slice onion, mince garlic, and trim scallions.
If using dried anchovies and kelp, bring water to a simmer with anchovies and a 5x5 cm piece of kelp for 5 minutes then remove solids to make quick stock. Otherwise use plain water.
Heat neutral oil in a medium heavy-bottomed pot over medium-high heat. Add sliced pork and sauté until edges begin to brown and fat renders.
Add sliced onion and minced garlic to the pork and sauté until fragrant and onions soften.
Add chopped kimchi and continue to cook, stirring, until kimchi softens and releases juices, about a few minutes.
Stir in gochujang, gochugaru, and soy sauce, coating kimchi and pork to bloom the spices.
Pour in the prepared stock or water, scraping any browned bits from the bottom, and bring to a gentle boil.
Reduce heat to medium-low and simmer uncovered for 12 minutes to meld flavors and tenderize the pork.
Gently add tofu cubes and half of the scallions to the pot, simmer 4–5 minutes just to heat through without breaking the tofu.
Taste and adjust seasoning with a small amount of sugar or extra soy sauce if needed. Drizzle sesame oil, garnish with remaining scallions and toasted sesame seeds, and serve hot with steamed rice.
